Oxford Preparatory School COVID-19 Remote Learning Information and Resources for Students & Parents Dear OPS Families, As you know, we are facing an unprecedented health crisis regarding the progression of the coronavirus (COVID-19). The OPS Board approved a remote learning plan that began o...

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":1,"s":"
Oxford Preparatory School 
COVID-19 Remote Learning Information and Resources for Students & Parents

Dear OPS Families,

As you know, we are facing an unprecedented health crisis regarding the progression of the coronavirus (COVID-19). The OPS Board approved a remote learning plan that began on Tuesday, March 17. As a result of Governor Cooper’s updated Executive Order on Friday 4/24/20, Oxford Preparatory School has ended traditional class meetings on campus effective Monday, March 16 and will continue the remote learning plan through the end of the school year on Wednesday, May 20, 2020. In addition, the NC State Board of Education submitted a federal testing waiver on 3/23/20, eliminating traditional year end tests (EOG/EOC/NCFE) for the 2019 - 2020 school year.

We know this decision greatly impacts our entire community and we have designed a plan to minimize the adverse impact to our students. As a result, school sponsored activities, spring athletics, performances, and field trips are cancelled. 

We are working on alternate plans for a commencement ceremony and hope to announce those soon. However, to be clear, these changes will not delay the graduation of our senior class. We understand that these developments are disappointing and saddening, but are essential to comply with the Governor’s order. As additional updates are finalized, we will share them here.

Best Regards,

Andrew Swanner
OPS Executive Director















Calendar and Schedule Information
Monday 3/16/20 - Oxford Preparatory School will be closed to students for a virtual staff workday. 

Tuesday 3/17/20 - OPS implemented a remote learning plan on Tuesday, 3/17/20, through the end of the school year on Wednesday, 5/20/20. 

Friday 4/3/20 - Beginning Friday 4/3 the OPS Campus, including the main office, will be closed until further notice. Anyone needing assistance can contact the appropriate OPS Employee by emailing them (OPS Staff Directory)

Friday 5/15/20 - Remote learning online will end.

Monday 5/18/20 - Wednesday 5/20/20 - Students return Chromebooks, textbooks, novels, spring sports uniforms, and any other materials that belong to the school. Limited access to the building will be provided to clean out lockers and collect any personal belongings that remain in the building.

Friday 5/29/20 - Report cards are placed in the mail to the addresses we have on file

Testing Updates
The NC State Board of Education submitted a federal testing waiver on 3/23/20, eliminating traditional year end tests (EOG/EOC/NCFE) for the 2019 - 2020 school year.
The College Board Announced Changes to AP Testing on 3/20/20















Updates to Grading Policies

Lower School

Per guidance from the state, OPS Lower School will continue to implement our remote learning plan through May 20th. The focus on our work and assignments will provide opportunities for all students to continue their academic growth. The focus of our teaching staff will be on being accessible to our students and providing meaningful feedback for student work. This will be accomplished through consistent communication and collection of evidence of learning. We will continue to enter grades in PowerSchool, however these will be one portion of the feedback students will receive and will be aligned to specific standard-based areas, targeting areas students need to develop in order to be successful in the upcoming school year. 


Grading Policy for 5th Grade

5th Grade students will not receive a final grade for the 2019-2020 school year. Instead, the school will develop an individualized report highlighting the student’s strengths and weaknesses to aid in the transition to the next grade level. This feedback should be used by families to guide areas of focus in their student development. Grade retention remains the discretion of the school administration. 

Grading Policy for 6th Grade

6th Grade students will not receive a grade lower than what they had on March 13th, at the end of 3rd quarter. All 6th grade students will receive one of two grades for their classes this year.

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":4101,"s":"
PC19 - This will be assigned to any student who was meeting expectations and passing the course as of March 13th (End of 3rd Quarter) OR, who worked to improve to the point of passing over the course of remote learning. 
WC19 - This will be assigned to students who were failing a course as of March 13th (end of 3rd quarter), AND has not been able to improve to the point of passing through remote learning. This grade is an indication of a lack of mastery of the standards in the specific content area.

In addition, the Lower School Staff will provide each family with an individualized report highlighting student areas of strength and weakness in academic and social areas to aid in the transition for the upcoming school year. 

Student promotion and retention decisions remain at the discretion of the school. 


Specials Classes

Given the unique nature of special classes, we will continue to develop assignments on a weekly basis that will help students develop their interests in arts and languages and help them maintain their emotional and physical well-being. These assignments will be given feedback on a completed / not complete basis, with the focus on developing the whole child. All assignments will be accepted through May 15th. Special teachers will be available to work with students individually as needed. At OPS, we believe that arts can have a profound effect on a child’s development and education and want for students to continue developing in these areas.



Upper School

Per guidance from the state, OPS Upper School will continue to implement our remote learning plan through May 20th. The focus on our work and assignments will provide opportunities for all students to continue their academic growth. The focus of our teaching staff will be on being accessible to our students, providing work that allows students to continue to grow and master both current and new concepts while providing meaningful feedback for student work. This will be accomplished through consistent, direct communication and collection of evidence of learning. We will continue to enter grades in PowerSchool, however these will be one portion of the feedback students will receive and will be aligned to specific standard-based areas. Assignments will continue to be developed on a weekly basis allowing for students to submit work in a manner that best meets their ability and needs at this time. 

Grades in Powerschool will reflect student engagement and work submission. At the end of each week, any missing assignments will receive a grade of zero. These assignments may still be turned in up to May 15th with no negative implication. In addition to homework and minor grades, beginning the week of April 12th, teachers may begin to assign meaningful work or assessments that would merit a major grade. If teachers wish to assign a “Major” grade for a subject area, they must notify the students in BOTH Google classroom and through a direct email at least one week in advance of the assignment (either assessment day / project due date). Any projects assigned that will be given a “Major” grade shall have an accompanying rubric that is detailed and easily understood. This rubric is to be provided to the students at the same time of the project assignment. Students who achieve less than a score of 70 on an assessment or major grade will be provided the opportunity to have an individual teleconference / Zoom meeting with the teacher and then may be allowed to re-submit the assignment for additional credit.

Students who were failing at the end of 3rd Quarter are being provided this opportunity to use remote learning as a means to boost their grades. For those students who had failing yearly grades averages at the end of 3rd quarter, their engagement and progress in remote learning will impact promotion decisions and decisions to grant credit for a class. No final exams will be given in any class; therefore, grades from each quarter are now weighted at 25% (50% in the case of semester classes).

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":8131,"s":"
2019-2020 Grading Policy Grades 7/8

Grading Policy for all traditional 7/8 courses
Students will not receive a grade lower than what they had at March 13, the end of 3rd quarter.

• All 7/8 Students will receive one of 2 grades for the year in each of their classes. They will
receive either a PC19 or a WC19 for all courses that are strictly for 7th or 8th grade credit.
There is a different policy for high school courses taken as a 7th or 8th grader. (See Below)

1. PC19 - for passing the course. Assigned to any student who was
• Meeting expectations and passing the course as of March 13 (end of 3rd quarter),
• OR, who worked to improve to the point of passing after March 13 through remote
learning.

2. WC19 - indicates lack of mastery and assigned to any student who was
• Failing a course as of March 13 (end of 3rd quarter) ,
• AND, has not been able to improve to the point of passing through remote learning.
• Powerschool grades for all regular 7/8th course enrollments will be displayed as either PC19 or WC19 for the year.
• Student promotion and retention remains the decision of the school.

Grading Policy for High School Classes taken in 2019/2020 during 7/8 grade
Students will be given a choice for how each final course grade will appear on the transcript for courses currently in progress.

• Students will have two options for each final course grade: They may choose
1. Numeric grade, the highest grade representing learning as of March 13, or as improved
through the semester as remote learning continued
2. OR, a PC19 or WC19.

• Advising sessions will be held with students and their parents during which they may
determine how each final course grade will appear on their transcript.
• When students in grades 7 or 8 who are taking high school courses choose to report a numeric grade as the final grade on the transcript, the numeric grade will NOT be calculated into the cumulative GPA. This is NOT a change from prior policies.
• Students in high school classes while in 7/8th grade and who had an overall grade of less than a C at the end of 3rd quarter will retake the high school class for credit the following year.

2019-2020 Grading Policy Grades 9-11 (Does NOT include Seniors!)
Grading Policy for High School Classes
Students will be given a choice for how each final course grade will appear on the transcript for courses currently in progress.

• Students will have two options for each final course grade: They may choose
1. Numeric grade, the highest grade representing learning as of March 13, or as
improved through the semester of remote learning
2. OR, a PC19 or WC19.

• CREDIT HOURS: Students who receive a PC 19 will receive the appropriate full or half unit of credit for the course. Students who choose a WC19 will receive NO units of credit.
• Advising sessions will be held with students and their parents during which they may
determine how each final course grade will appear on their transcript.
• Students in grades 9 - 11 who choose to report a numeric grade as the final grade on the
transcript WILL have that grade calculated into the cumulative GPA.

• SEMESTER CLASSES:
• SPRING SEMESTER CLASSES: Students who choose to report a PC19 or WC19 on their transcript will have NO GPA impact. PC19 will result in 0.5 credits. WC19 receives no
credit.
• FALL SEMESTER CLASSES: Grades from fall semester classes will not be affected in any way. Students will still get the appropriate credits for the class and the grade will be used in the calculation of GPA.
• YEAR LONG CLASSES: Students who choose to report a PC19 or WC 19 on their transcript will have the grade from the fall semester counted into their GPA, and then receive either a PC19 or WC19 for the spring semester.
• Students who receive no credit for a class, will retake the class for credit.





SENIORS - CLASS OF 2020 ONLY

For seniors graduating in the spring of 2020 only, all classes will be treated as semester classes. The grade in the class at the end of the 1st (Fall) semester shall be used as the grade for that semester and will be the grade used to calculate final GPA. All classes for the 2nd (Spring) semester will receive a PC-19 and no letter grade. In other words, if a senior member of the class of 2020 had an overall semester average grade of 89 (B) at the end of 1st semester for US History 2, then that is the grade that will be used in their GPA. For the second semester of US History 2 they will receive a PC-19.

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":12598,"s":"
Failing grades for first semester will be used to determine graduation eligibility and GPA. If it is determined that the students needs the course to meet minimum NC graduation requirements, then they may demonstrate their learning and obtain credit towards graduation in the following ways: 
Participate in remote learning, 
Participate in credit recovery aligned to instructional topics covered through March 13; OR 
Pass a final locally developed assessment aligned to instructional topics covered through March 13. 
Upon meeting these requirements, the student would receive credit for the class and will have a PC-19 for Semester 2. This does not change the GPA determined using grades from S1

The minimum graduation requirements for the North Carolina are: 

ENGLISH - 4 Credits
English I, II, III, IV or a designated combination of four (4) courses
MATH - 4 Credits
Math I, II, III plus a designated fourth math
SCIENCE - 3 Credits
A physical science, Earth & Environmental Science and Biology
HISTORY - 4 Credits
American History: Founding Principles and Civics, World History, US History I and US History II
HEALTH & PHYSICAL EDUCATION - 1 credit
Health & Physical Education
ELECTIVES - 6 credits
2 credits from foreign language or arts; 4 credits from any other elective subject
TOTAL CREDITS REQUIRED - 22 Credits





Service Opportunities for Students
15 service hours needs to be documented and approved for every OPS Upper School (7th - 12th Grade) Student each year. Seniors must submit by 4/27/20 and 7th - 11th Grade Students must submit by 5/11/20. Please refer to https://www.oxfordprep.org/Student-Service-Program where the OPS student service guidelines, service log form, and new opportunities are posted that can be completed during this time of social distancing. 



Resources for Internet Connectivity
The OPS Building has opened Public Wifi access that should be accessible in the parking lot close to the building. Anyone using this service should remain in their vehicle.
NC Department of Technology Internet Service Offerings Interactive Map
Local Public Libraries have wireless connections available inside and often accessible from the parking lot when/if the library is closed
Many of the major internet service providers signed the FCC agreement Friday, March 13th to keep customers connected during the COVID-19 outbreak and will not cut off any service due to non-payments. They have also opened their hotspots for free access in cities that have coverage. 
Comcast Service is being offered free for two months with the option to continue service for $10/month for low income families in their service area. They can apply online here https://www.internetessentials.com/covid19 or contact via phone 855-846-8376 for English speakers or 855-765-6995 for Spanish speakers
Spectrum/Charter is also offering 2 months service free with all installation fees waived for any household with a K-12 or college student who does not have service currently by calling 844-488-8395
AT&T and Sprint are lifting their data caps and overage charges during the outbreaks
Other providers may follow with similar options next week following the signed pledge on March 13th. 
https://www.digital-one.com/wireless-broadband-rental
Verizon Jetpack Rental
$40/week or $60/month + $20 roundtrip shipping and a 1-5 day turnaround 
https://daypasswireless.com/#bkrent
Verizon and Sprint Jetpack Rental
Pricing varies on length of time – 2 weeks is $6.75/day + $9.90 roundtrip shipping
Delivered to mailbox, but no local storefront locations
https://www.skyroam.com/skyroam-hotspot-rental
Skyroam Hotspot
$9/day unlimited data use


School Nutrition
OPS will offer weekly lunch bags for students available for pickup on Tuesday 3/31 & Thursday 4/2 from 3:00 - 6:00
Additional School Nutrition Resources
FOUR WAYS TO FIND FREE, HEALTHY MEALS FOR KIDS AGE 18 AND UNDER:
1. Text FOODNC to 877-877 to receive a text with the three drive-thru or pick up sites with meals for kids closest to you.

3. Visit NoKidHungryNC.org/MealUpdates for information on delivery meals by bus and other updates from school districts and community partners serving meals.
4. Check your local school district's website, social media, and other communications for the most up-to-date information.



Tech Support
Oxford Preparatory School students and faculty/staff can use the linked form below to request support with any problems they may be experiencing in accessing school related technology (Google Classroom, Chromebook, etc.).

Tech Request for Support


Content Filtering At Home:
Content Filtering generally is only controlled in the school building and in these cases would not follow the student home. Content filtering at home is generally the responsibility of the parent to control and monitor.
Personal devices can be controlled using parental controls, but school owned devices usually do not allow for those changes or accounts to be owned by the parent. There are a few non-intrusive options that will help provide a stricter content access on any device used by students in the household regardless of configuration: 
Parents can contact their internet service provider directly to assist them with setting up a stricter network filtering. By default, the router that is provided with internet service at home is set up with lowest restrictions and thus all content is available to any user on the network. 
Parents can find the instructions for changing the content filtering levels on their router on their own if they are comfortable doing it without involving the internet service provider. Manuals for their exact device are available online with the model being printed on a label on the router and the login IP address and credentials are listed on the label as well.
Parents can setup a free OpenDNS account and create customized filtering. They have two options: one is to block adult content and it does it all for you (OpenDNS Family Shield) while the other allows for more customization, like separating child devices from parent devices and category blocking for a stricter network (OpenDNS Home). Both have tutorials that walk parents through the setup process. https://www.opendns.com/home-internet-security/
